Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: My dog becomes vocal in the hallway when people pass near shared doors.
Expectation2: Conduct experiments to test hypotheses and gather data
Situation2: The experiment can be run on several upcoming dates, and skipping this slot would not disrupt the overall timeline.
Story: I stood in my apartment, clipboard in hand, reviewing the schedule for my next experiment. The lab had finally approved my request for extra time, and I could run the tests as early as tomorrow. It was a rare opportunity, and I felt the familiar thrill of anticipation. Just then, I heard my dog, Max, barking loudly in the hallway. His barks echoed off the walls, and I winced, knowing how thin these old building walls were. My neighbor, Mrs. Lee, had already mentioned how the noise startled her during her evening reading. I wanted to be a good neighbor, to respect the shared spaces and keep the peace. But if I left Max alone while I spent hours in the lab, he’d surely bark even more, disturbing everyone. I could postpone the experiment, but the data was important, and I didn’t want to lose momentum. The weight of both roles pressed on me—my responsibility to my neighbors and my commitment to my research—leaving me torn, standing in the hallway with Max’s leash in one hand and my lab notes in the other, uncertain what to do next.
